file_content.text: What do you want from me? I've done everything I can.
Hold on, I gotta shock this Twi'lek slave again.
Hrmph. What are you doing here? Sightseeing? Soak in the ambience but stay out of the way.
Well, he didn't put up much of a fight, did he?
Torture and old age had weakened him.
How could he?
He died a warrior.
That wasn't the point.
I've fought fiercer colds.
He was pathetic.
I'm surprised. She faced her death well.
Dead just the same.
Doesn't change anything.
I admire her for that.
She died bravely.
I spit on her remains.
Still a disgusting lowlife.
Please, I am a fellow Sith. Grant me the same opportunity you afforded the assassin. I deserve a trial by combat. I beg you.
One more chirp from you, little bird, and you'll regret it.
Chirp. Chirp, chirp.
Hrmph. I warned you.
Ow! Jerk. If you don't like that, just say so. I can do other animals, too. Dire-cat, frog-dog, Kowakian monkey-lizard, you name it.
I can set this controller to perpetual shock if you like, slave.
Um, as fun as that sounds, I think, uh, I think I'll pass.
That's what I thought. Now, keep it shut, I got a visitor.
You. I'm Jailer Knash. I run these cells and slave pits. You're the acolyte Tremel sent for the test, right? Hrmph. He thinks highly of you.
Then I will repay his faith by sticking to my mission.
Something I try to live up to.
That's good to hear, I want to do well.
I'm pleased.
You should know this situation is highly unusual. Normally, an acolyte goes offworld for the interrogation, Overseer Tremel had these three shipped in for you.
He thinks you're the next coming of Exar Kun. But you ought to know, Tremel ain't the only one paying attention to you.
Not a concern.
Right, hrmph, your crud don't stink. But during this trial, you think on what I said.
Good to know.
Don't say I never gave you nothing. Keep it in mind during the task.
Is that a fact?
We're all being watched, kid, all the time. Remember that as you face this trial.
Skip the pleasantries.
No skin off my rump.
Now, these three prisoners have been transferred here for your inspection. You gotta interrogate them as needed, and then decide their fate.
The convicted are usually executed or given a trial by combat to see if they're worthy. Whatever you decide, you will be the one to carry out the sentence.
Of course.
Let's have some fun.
Show me to these soon-to-be-dead lowlifes.
The convicts will bleed.
Hrmph. Fine, let's get started. This one on the left--
You freaks aren't getting anything new out of me. Just do whatever you're gonna do.
You can either talk to me or to the inquisitors. And I promise, I have a much sunnier disposition.
I can be reasonable.
Get lost. I've been through this routine. I already know all your inquisitors by name.
So, you're hoping for blind mercy? Do you know where you are, lady?
Don't expect leniency.
You don't have to tell me. There's no such thing as mercy here. I know how this story ends.
Let me make this plain as day. If you don't cooperate, I will kill you.
Do you want to die?
I'm not afraid to die.
Impudent to the last. As I was saying, she was sent to kill an Imperial spy in the Yavin system. Throughout her torture, she maintained that she was hired anonymously.
Get it through your damn head--I had no idea he was Imperial, and I don't know who hired me.
So, you're telling me you're not a Republic assassin?
You have no ties to the enemy?
I'm not political. I work for whoever pays.
Murder is a serious charge. Do you regret what you did?
Where's your remorse?
Are you for real? No, I love how this turned out.
Regale me with the details of your operation. What was your chosen form of murder?
Tell me about the killing.
I didn't kill him. I was caught before I could pull it off.
The point is, she doesn't deny the charge. So, now you must decide--execution or trial by combat. Which do you choose?
She deserves to die. I'll kill her where she stands.
Execution. [Kill her]
Be my guest.
Just get it over with.
Huh. She faced her death well.
I admire her for that.
She died bravely.
Too bad she didn't beg.
A pity. I like them broken.
I spit on her remains.
She earned my contempt.
Please, I am a fellow Sith, spare me the assassin's ignoble fate. Grant me a trial by combat. I beg you.
Her spirit is unbroken. Give this woman a weapon. She will fight for her life.
Arm her.
Whatever you say, kid.
This is stupid. Give me the damn sword.
Neither actually. She could prove useful. Send her to Imperial Intelligence.
The Empire needs assassins.
I won't work for free.
Hrmph. You spared her. Interesting.
Please, I am a fellow Sith, judge me with an open mind and grant me trial by combat. I beg you.
Who are you?
Oh, you want to fight? You don't actually think you can beat me, do you?
You'll lose.
Pipe down, scum. You will speak when spoken to.
Shut up.
This pile of waste is Devotek. Once a valued Sith champion, until he botched an important mission and caused a thousand Imperial deaths. Now look at him.
I served faithfully for twenty-four years, then one mistake and they threw me away.
Now, I have been left here to rot. Please, let me feel the weight of a weapon once more.
I will grant your wish. A warrior should die with his boots on.
Jailer, give him a sword.
My thanks, young warrior.
Hrmph. This should be entertaining.
You're not worth the effort. Live on in shame.
Continue to rot.
Then I am misery. Languishing here is worse than death.
Heh, and I thought his disgrace had already hit rock bottom.
There are always new depths to discover. I bet he can sink even lower.
Disgrace knows no bounds.
Who knows? With time, maybe he'll rediscover his mettle.
He might find his nerve.
I'm sick of thinking about him. Let's just move on.
Who's next?
I don't do charity work. Feel the weight of a weapon in your throat!
No, you die. [Kill him]
I die a disgrace.
Good. I won't have to look at his sad, weathered face anymore. Thank you.
That man served for a long time. You should be more respectful.
Honor his sacrifice.
You're welcome.
And he won't have to look at yours either, jailer.
You shouldn't talk.
Hrmph. Well, this last prisoner is a bit of a puzzle. He's called Brehg, and he's a jittery little wretch, suspected of supplying forged documents to Republic agents.
Strangely enough, he maintains his innocence despite being severely tortured.
That's because innocent I am! Believe me, you gotta--I had nothing to do with forging no papers. Set up, I was set up!
Come on, who would go to all the trouble of setting you up?
That seems unlikely.
No idea. Absolutely none.
Are you trying to tell me you've led a clean life?
So you're not a criminal?
Well, that I never said.
Your ramblings are falling on deaf ears. Confess and the torture will stop.
I'm not buying it.
Many things I've done in my life that I'm not proud of, but Brehg's not gonna confess to something Brehg didn't do.
Did some time, I did, in a Republic jail for forgery, so I was the perfect candidate to implicate in this. But straight I've been since getting out, I swear!
Hrmph. He's never wavered from that line, and the evidence is circumstantial. I suppose it's actually possible he didn't do it. So, what do you decide?
This matter is beneath me. Throw him back in his cell.
Leave him in chains.
No, don't, don't turn no blind eye to injustice! I beg you!
Well, I guess it's back to solitary for him.
I think in this case we should release him. Let him go.
Set him free.
Did I just hear you say what I think I heard you say? There's some justice in the world. Thanks to you!
Freedom, huh? That's a new one.
I don't care if he's innocent or not. Torture him enough and he'll confess.
Bleed him until he relents.
Please, no, not fair, it's just not fair!
Shut up, you fidgety fool. The decision's been made.
Hrmph. Well, that's that. You're an interesting one, kid. I can see why people are keeping tabs on you. Head back to Overseer Tremel, see what he thinks of your choices.
Go away, acolyte, I'm busy.
Hrmph. I think you're lost, kid. I got nothing for you.
Hrmph. Got a lot to do here. Try to stay out of the way.
